title: 109_hr4400
content: The "Children's Hope Act of 2005" allows for tax credits for contributions to education investment organizations under section 30D of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Children's Hope Act of 2005" allows for tax credits for qualified contributions to education investment organizations, limited to $100 for individuals and $200 for joint returns. Qualified contributions are charitable donations to organizations disbursing grants to students. The "Children's Hope Act of 2005" allows tax credits for qualified contributions to education investment organizations, disbursed as grants to students for elementary and secondary education expenses. At least half of the disbursements must go to students eligible for free or reduced-cost lunches. Qualified expenses are defined as per section 530(b)(4), with certain substitutions. No taxpayer can claim a credit under this section unless they are eligible for the minimum State qualified scholarship tax credit on their State tax return. Contributions considered for the State qualified scholarship tax credit cannot be used for this credit. Additionally, no double benefit can be claimed for expenses that qualify for this credit. For tax purposes, contributions to an education investment organization are considered made on the last day of the previous taxable year if made before the deadline for filing the tax return. Scholarships from these organizations for elementary and secondary education expenses are excluded from gross income. Scholarships for elementary and secondary education expenses are excluded from gross income and not considered for Federal program eligibility. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subpart B. The amendments made by Sec. 30D apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2004. Federal scholarship tax credit is dependent on state qualified scholarship tax credit. The scholarship tax credit must meet certain requirements to be considered a State qualified scholarship tax credit, including a minimum amount of $250 per taxpayer and being allowed against State income tax or property tax. For a scholarship tax credit to be considered a State qualified scholarship tax credit, it must meet specific requirements such as a minimum amount of $250 per taxpayer and being applicable against State income tax or property tax. Additionally, the excess credit over tax liability can be carried forward for up to five years, the contribution cannot be restricted to benefit a specific child, and the credit is not allowed for direct donations to private schools. A school tuition organization must operate in the State, be a 501(c)(3) organization exempt from tax, and spend at least 90% of its annual cash contributions on educational scholarships or tuition. A qualified school is defined as an elementary or secondary school in the taxpayer's state that does not discriminate and meets state requirements. An educational scholarship or tuition grant allows children to attend any qualified school chosen by their parents. The school tuition organization must disburse at least 90% of its annual cash contributions within one year. An "educational scholarship or tuition grant" refers to a scholarship or grant awarded for qualified elementary and secondary education expenses. The term "State" in this context refers to any of the several States.
